key_insight: ReaSeq enriches ID-based sequential recommenders by injecting world knowledge and explicit reasoning into item/user representations, enabling models to infer beyond-log interests and remain robust under sparse interaction data.
problem_solved: Overcomes knowledge poverty in ID-only item embeddings and the closed-loop blindness of log-driven recommenders by leveraging external semantic/world knowledge and reasoning to capture latent user interests beyond platform logs.
method: Map item IDs to rich semantic representations using external sources (e.g., knowledge graphs or pretrained language models) to recover product/world knowledge.
Apply a lightweight reasoning module (chain-of-thought / inference over facts) to derive latent user intents and beyond-log interests from enriched item semantics.
Fuse the reasoned semantic signals with sequential modeling (e.g., session/trajectory encoder) so downstream ranking or next-item prediction uses both interaction patterns and world knowledge.
impact: Makes sequential recommenders more data-efficient and generalizable—better cold-start performance, fewer brittle predictions under sparse logs, and the ability to recommend items aligned with users' off-platform interests.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: ID inputs → semantic enrichment (KG/LM) → reasoning module → fused sequential encoder → recommendation output
Before vs after bar chart: improvement in cold-start / sparse-user accuracy or coverage when adding world knowledge
Schematic of closed-loop blindness vs. beyond-log reasoning: shows missing off-platform interests recovered by reasoning
Embedding space visualization (t-SNE) showing ID-only vs. knowledge-enriched item clusters
paper_title: ReaSeq: Unleashing World Knowledge via Reasoning for Sequential Modeling
paper_authors: Chuan Wang, Gaoming Yang, Han Wu, Jiakai Tang, Jiahao Yu
